column1: In Chiafalo v. Washington, will the Supreme Court rule that the state of Washington's fining of presidential electors for failing to vote for the nominee of their party is unconstitutional?
column6: ['Elections and Referenda']

7/6/20: "Electoral College voters can be forced to abide by state popular vote, Supreme Court says" (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/06/supreme-court-electoral-college-ruling-states-can-force-electors-to-abide-by-popular-vote.html)
The Supreme Court will determine that electors must represent the wished of their state and that this requirement is implied in the U.S. Constitution and directly stated in the state law.

The original-intent strict-construction crowd are presumably suffering the tortures of the darned on this one. It is obvious from everything their 18th-Century heroes wrote about this that they meant electors to exercise their own judgement. It has been obvious from about the John Adams administration forward that the original model has been consigned to the dustbin of history. It is not obvious, but a possibility terrifying to those very people, that truly independent electors could destroy the two-party system that has secured their comfy jobs and ideological certainty.

I think there are several factors confounding the crowd here: 1) as with any political question there are going to be those who can't separate their wishes from their predictions. 2) The way the question is written is confusing (because it's complicated, not because GJO did a bad job of writing the question).

Oral argument was not of much help in predicting the case result. It is true though that Brett Kavanaugh's questioning focused on the "chaos" argument. "Chaos" argument, btw, favours the Electors because most of US electoral history has not been marked by chaos even though states by and large have not fired or disciplined the few faithless Electors that turn up from time to time.
Wow.

After re-reading the testimony here is what I think will happen. The Court will not find it unconstitutional if an elector is sworn to an oath in a Court and then does not follow through then they can be punished for perjury. They will find a state can set conditions right up to the time if the vote and remove anyone who says they are not going to vote the way expected. If they are allowed to vote their vote will count no matter how they voted. What if they voted against state’s wishes. There is nothing saying the states can’t punish for that but the term elector as opposed to delegate means ‘their discretion’. Tough one but a ruling that is narrow to this case might happen. It will say not done right in these cases but not unconstitutional if set-up right by the ‘legal’ oath.

Supreme Court just delayed arguments due to Coronavirus. They might not get to this. You could say originally the State Legislature chose the elector and then the Elector met with other Electors and chose the President. Happened in first two elections but thereafter it has been the Electors are nameless bodies following their state’s dictates. The 12th Amendment states the States have the power to chose their Electors. After thinking about this it could well be that they can set expectations for Electors after they are chosen and punish if those are not met. Court could take middle way and say Constitution says nothing about what an elector is beyond their role as voter but does give a State the power to chose them. It can have criteria for the chose. So status quo? Elector can vote anyway and State can fine. It is up to the State to chose people to agree to do their bidding. The Court seems to be originalist but overturn 200 years of process? I have gone back and forth on this but this is my final answer.

Colorado law is more clearly unconstitutional than Washington law. However, invalidating Colorado law and upholding Washington law will not happen because obviously a fine to coerce an Elector into voting a specific way ultimately achieves the same purpose as replacing a faithless Elector. So both statutes have to be invalidated.

Since State law mandates EC voters to cast their ballots for the presidential candidates from their party who won the popular vote in the state not ruling it as unconstitutional will set a future precedence of chaos

SCOTUS is unlikely to officially rule on this issue, although if they do they will be seriously split as both sides have much to gain or lose by either supporting or not supporting faithless voters. In all fairness, fining faithless Electoral college voters is the enforcement of democracy. What is the purpose of voting if the EC is going to vote however they feel like. Then, for those justices where politics takes precedent, why wouldn't they find it unconstitutional to fine someone when they retain party control through allowing faithless votes? I could easily see RBG stating it is unconstitutional, Roberts saying it is not, Sotomayer voting it is not, Kavanaugh is a no and could not begin to assess anyone elses attitude towards the subject matter.

NCLS.Org: Article II states: “[e]ach State shall appoint, in such Manner as the Legislature thereof may direct, a Number of Electors.” The Twelfth Amendment states that electors “vote by [distinct] ballot for president and vice president,” and that the candidates receiving votes for president or vice president constituting a majority of the electors appointed are elected to those respective offices. The Tenth Circuit concluded that Colorado lacks the authority to require electors to vote for the candidate receiving the most votes because “the definitions of elector, vote, and ballot [contained in Article II and the Twelfth Amendment] have a common theme: they all imply the right to make a choice or voice an individual opinion.”

While the first amendment states that congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances, those are individuals rights who have not entered into a contract. Washington has ruled to uphold the fine, Colorado has ruled on the side of the elector, putting the split at 50/50 and as of January 22, the Supreme Court has announced they will hear the cases. There has been precedence set, in the 1952 case Ray vs Blair, the Supreme Court held that “presidential electors exercise a federal function in balloting for President and Vice-President but they are not federal officers or agents” suggesting that states may retain more control over an elector than they do over a sitting member of Congress or a president. Electors, according to Ray, “act by authority of the state that in turn receives its authority from the Federal Constitution.” Based on the current split, and the previous ruling, I cast my 25% probability vote.

In any event, I think it's very unlikely they write new law about how state electors cast their ballots for presidential candidates.

I believe they will uphold the decision, so my choice should be 7%. I misread the question. What I mean is, no they will not find the fining unconstitutional. The way the question was framed was confusing.

I see what people are saying about a poll tax but that is before someone votes this is a punishment for after the vote. I sympathize with the sentiments but the law seems different. I no longer like the electoral college.

“Each State shall appoint, in such Manner as the Legislature thereof may direct,” — The Constitution I take it a yes here means they will not find it unconstitutional.
avenues in settled case law (Koller); states rights deference doctrine.

I really have not spent any time analyzing this case. The questions is who benefits in this highly partisan climate. The four liberal justices will likely vote to limit or reduce the slant the electoral college gives small conservative states. I suspect their dissent will be something usual.

This question is not can the state control the electors but can the state fine an elector for breaking their pledge when being appointed. Maybe the point of the fine is to control the elector or maybe the fine is to limit the pool of candidates for elector to only those who will not vote in bad faith. The petitioner are saying the purpose of the fine is to control the elector after being appointed (probaly intrudes on federal roles). Washington is saying its a fine for making a false pledge (definetly a State role). A $1000 fine is not going to control an elector decision. A $100,000 fine probably would control the elector decision. I think the court fudges and says the State can fine but the fine can not be so large as to prevent the elector from executing their independent judgement to select an elector. Why not just say the State is not allowed to levy any fine? Because the State has the right to establish the conditions for the appointment of electors and if an elector intentionally violates those conditions then there should be a penalty for bad faith. As I said its a fudge. They fudge to keep the ruling narrow, no large sweeping opinions. Just recognize what everyone agrees on. Electors make a choice, States appoint electors, and the current system has fines. The decision can be written not to upset Blair. What the decision accomplishes is a flag to electors that they can vote their conscience, and more will do just that, and we have more court cases in the future. Heck, this could even become a whole new right/left split for the voting population, like Whigs vs Federalists.
Thinking more carefully on this (although not an American legal expert):
I really don't see the Supremes upending the precedent set forth in Ray v. Blair, 343 US 214, 232 (1952).

Still guessing for now that the Court will choose not to upend "...long-standing practice regarding the operation of the Electoral College", but also tend to agree (per article linked below) that: "..."No one faithful to our history can deny that the plan originally contemplated, what is implicit in its text, is that electors would be free agents, to exercise an independent and nonpartisan judgment as to the [individuals] best qualified for the Nation's highest offices." Ray v. Blair, 343 US 214, 232 (1952)."

Macleans magazine (link below) suggests that the mood in America is one that is increasingly supportive of existing elites. Members of the Supreme Court, like any other individuals, are influenced by the mood of the day. Thus it is more likely that the SCOTUS will support the existing rules. https://www.macleans.ca/opinion/america-in-2020-king-george-gets-his-revenge/
The conservative majority is likely to take the "originalist" interpretation, which was that electors should exercise their own judgment.

They'll want to get the issue decided promptly so there will be a clear answer for this year's election. There is no explicit constitutional basis to forbid states from instructing their electors, and fining them for violating instructions. The originalist mystics and the states' rights fundamentalists will see this immediately. However, both of those cults have in the past proven impressively elastic in their application of their ostensibly rock-hard principles, so this isn't a shoo-in.

The SCOTUS is compromised as a facilitator of GOP conservative extremism, which demands "party over country" loyalty in order to consolidate power. Placing electors in the right spots & demanding their party-line vote is essential to the GOPs future. The SCOTUS will leave the door open to partisan extremism with its' forthcoming decision in this case.

In Chiafalo v. Washington, will the Supreme Court rule that the state of Washington's fining of presidential electors for failing to vote for the nominee of their party is unconstitutional? By agreeing to hear the case they have made a statement.

I think the Supreme Court will defer to states as to how they manage their electors. As I read the Constitution, the electors are part of a slate but are not bound to vote for any particular person. I think the Court will defer to the states on this. My casual reading of the Constitution and the 12th Amendment is there is no restriction on how electors are bound to behave with respect to this issue.

In Chiafalo v. Washington, will the Supreme Court rule that the state of Washington's fining of presidential electors for failing to vote for the nominee of their party is unconstitutional? There are cascaded "ifs" in this question and questions I cannot answer, but it is a good one to follow. I'll be at a respectful distance.
In my reading, it is unconstitutional.
